name: Russia
takeaway: China and the Russian Federation have close cooperation in many areas, including media, law, and social spheres. This means that the Russian Federation can adopt China's practices in citizen control, privacy, freedom of expression, media censorship, and so on. In addition to regular meetings of foreign ministers during reciprocal visits and on the sidelines of international forums, there is a system of scheduled consultations between the Russian and Chinese foreign ministries at the level of deputy ministers and department heads. The Russia-China nexus has firmly established itself as a key factor in maintaining international security and stability, establishing a multipolar world order, democratizing global governance mechanisms, and ensuring the rule of international law. At various levels of government, approvals of China's policies are expressed, and they are mostly positive.

Russian-Chinese relations are officially defined by the parties as relations of comprehensive partnership and strategic cooperation entering a new era. Its basic principles and directions of development are reflected in the Treaty on Good-Neighborliness, Friendship and Cooperation between the Russian Federation and the PRC of July 16, 2001. In total, more than 300 intergovernmental treaties and agreements have been concluded, covering practically all areas of cooperation. The Treaty of Good-Neighborliness defined the basic principle of bilateral relations: China and Russia have always lived in friendship and will never be enemies. Russia has also reaffirmed its commitment to the one China principle and opposes Taiwan independence in any form. This is disclosed in the joint statement on deepening relations of comprehensive partnership and strategic cooperation between the Russian Federation and the PRC into a new era.

The ideas of Sovereignization of the Runet (Russian Internet) are already closer to the ideas of the PRC’s Golden Shield, although it currently operates in a limited mode - and only in relation to those resources that pose the greatest threat to the Kremlin. But blocking and restrictions on VPN use are increasingly looking like the Chinese version of regulation.

After the start of Russia's military operation in Ukraine and the imposition of sanctions by the US, Europe and their allies, Moscow redirected significant volumes of oil and coal to China. Chinese companies increased their exports to Russia, taking advantage of the withdrawal of many Western companies from the Russian market. Thus, by the end of 2022, trade turnover between the two countries increased by almost 30%, reaching a record $190.3 billion. For example, Chinese exports of goods to Russia increased by 12.8% to $76.1 billion, while imports from Russia increased by 43.4% to $114.1 billion. In 2023, after the introduction of a number of sanctions from the West, including a ban on the export of devices over $200 to Russia. China significantly increased imports of Chinese mobile phones into Russia, which are now distributed with pre-installed Russian application stores (RuStores). Now Chinese manufacturers occupy 75% of the mobile device market, which is 25% more than a year earlier. It is obvious that control over devices imported into the country with pre-installed and government-approved applications allows for increased control and censorship in the Russian online space.

The Chairman of the Supreme Council of United Russia, Boris Gryzlov, announced at a joint event with the Communist Party of China the creation of a platform for "international party interaction" at the Russian State Social University, at which a social rating system similar to the Chinese one is being developed. The platform will be called the International Center for Sustainable Development. In his speech, Boris Gryzlov said that the purpose of the International Center will be to "unite supporters of the multipolar world" and preserve traditional values. "We see how the multipolar architecture of international relations takes on clearer and clearer contours," he said.
description-1: In 2023, Russia had a GDP per capita of US$13,817 and a total population of 145.68 million people.
description-2: The Soviet Union established diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China on October 2, 1949. After the collapse of the USSR in 1991, the Russian Federation continued these relations with the PRC. Russia was ranked 162nd in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Not Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 13/100.

Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Journalists from Russian regions visited China's largest cities as part of a press tour in November 2023. The media representatives visited Beijing, Xi'an, and Chengdu, where they familiarized themselves with the history and development of these major cities, as well as cultural attractions of global significance.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Media.note: As far as we can see, Russian journalists from state-owned media mostly participate in bilateral media forums or dialogues (https://rg.ru/2023/09/22/26-sentiabria-kitajsko-rossijskij-dialog-molodyh-zhurnalistov.html) and new media forums (https://tass.ru/press-relizy/13076523). These events typically focus on new ways of spreading traditional media information via the internet. There is no evidence of journalists, media organizations, or online influencers in our country receiving training from PRC state-owned media or PRC-connected entities.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Russian-language editorial offices are some of the largest within the Chinese state external propaganda system. This extensive infrastructure supports the broadcasting and distribution of PRC state media, including print, radio, and video, in local languages. Consequently, PRC state media content is indeed broadcasted or distributed in the local language in our country.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: According to current Russian legislation regulating the media sphere, foreign citizens and legal entities may not act as founders of mass media outlets (Article 19.1 of the Law of the Russian Federation "On Mass Media").
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Media editorial boards and journalists very rarely report incidents of censorship by their founders. Pressure from founders has not been discussed in the press, making it unlikely to find online data on this.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: The media often use words like "friendship," "mutual understanding," "trust," and "similar views" when describing relations between Russia and China.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Russian media often write from a position of endorsing China's policy on controversial issues.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Friendship groups have been established for cooperation with different countries (parliaments) around the world. However, there are no confirmations of active work by such groups in recent years.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.note: Although there were instances at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic when China provided Russia with medical equipment as part of its worldwide "Vaccine Diplomacy" or "Healthcare Silk Road" initiative, this cannot be considered as foreign aid.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: According to our expert, such training is conducted as part of "exchanges" between MGIMO and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation, but the details of these exchanges are not public. In November 2023, a delegation from MGIMO visited Beijing, where the Chinese side proposed creating a joint master's program between MGIMO and the Diplomatic Academy of the People's Republic of China for the training and education of diplomats. This program would involve gradual training in both Russia and China.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: The cases are isolated and hardly politically motivated. For example, the report from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation on violations of the rights of Russian citizens and compatriots in foreign countries does not include China.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: "Joint Statement of the Russian Federation and the People's Republic of China on the Development of Relations of Comprehensive Partnership and Strategic Cooperation Entering a New Era," June 6, 2019.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Nowadays, Russian-Chinese relations are officially defined by both parties as relations of comprehensive partnership and strategic interaction entering a new era. The basic principles and directions of their development are reflected in the Treaty on Good Neighborliness, Friendship, and Cooperation between the Russian Federation and the People's Republic of China, signed on July 16, 2001. In total, more than 300 intergovernmental treaties and agreements have been concluded, covering practically all areas of cooperation.
Foreign Policy.note: On March 20, 2023, Chinese President Xi Jinping paid a three-day official visit to Moscow. Following the visit, the heads of Russia and China signed a joint statement on deepening the strategic partnership between the two countries.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Russia reaffirms its commitment to the "one China" principle and opposes Taiwan independence in any form. This is stated in the joint statement on deepening the relations of comprehensive partnership and strategic cooperation between the Russian Federation and the PRC, which are entering a new era.
Foreign Policy.note: However, it is worth mentioning that there are semi-official relations between the Russian Federation and the Republic of China (ROC). There is a Representative Office in Moscow for the Taipei-Moscow Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, operating in accordance with Presidential Order No. 479-OP dated September 2, 1992, and registered in the companies register as an international non-governmental organization.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: The support is tacit as part of the current Russian regime's "special" relationship with the PRC. Details are not publicly disclosed.
Foreign Policy.note: Back in 2021, Russia retained a neutral stance on the territorial controversies in the South China Sea region. As the official representative of the Russian Foreign Ministry, Maria Zakharova, noted, "Our country’s position on this issue is consistent and unchanged. Russia is not a party to territorial disputes in the South China Sea and, as a matter of principle, does not take sides. We believe that the relevant consultations and negotiations should be conducted directly by the parties involved in a format determined by them themselves." It seems that in 2022, the stance remained the same.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: The support is tacit. In fact, China's actions are endorsed as part of the "fight against international (Islamic) terrorism." The media emphasizes that other countries oppose the oppression of Uyghurs and broadcasts China's opinion that such accusations are slanderous. In 2021, Russian President Vladimir Putin made rather elusive statements, suggesting that the general Uyghur population supports Chinese policy. However, he noted that there are always some discontented individuals and claimed that it was not his place to evaluate the situation from the outside.
Foreign Policy.note: The tacit support or elusive stance could be influenced by the significant number of Muslims in Russia, who represent a majority in certain constituents of the Federation. It should be noted that the government does not tend to express anything concrete or explicit about certain policy decisions relevant to the indicator.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: The same applies to the Uyghur population. The "savagery" and "uncivilizedness" of the Tibetan authorities before and after the arrival of "civilized" Chinese "liberators" is periodically noted at the expert level, without wide media coverage.
Foreign Policy.note: The government does not tend to express anything concrete or explicit about certain policy decisions relevant to the indicator. In February 2023, only a general assurance of support to China in Tibet, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Xinjiang was given by Nikolai Patrushev, the Secretary of the Russian Security Council.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Tacit support. The events preceding and accompanying the adoption of the Hong Kong law were generally covered in the media with sympathetic support for the actions of the central authorities and condemnation of the "extremists." The media emphasized that other countries, such as the European Union, Canada, the United Kingdom, and Australia, were opposed to the law.
Foreign Policy.note: The government does not tend to express anything concrete or explicit about certain policy decisions relevant to the indicator. In February 2023, only a general assurance of support for China in Tibet, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Xinjiang was given by Nikolai Patrushev, the Secretary of the Russian Security Council.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: The HSE School of Business Informatics signed an agreement to relaunch its partnership with Huawei. This cooperation will allow students to master unique educational programs and participate in specialized research with the industry leader. Additionally, an authorized Huawei info-communication academy was established at Ural Federal University.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There are 19 Confucius Institutes and 4 Confucius Schools in Russia, located in cities such as Moscow, St. Petersburg, Volgograd, Novosibirsk, Irkutsk, Vladivostok, Kazan, Ulan-Ude, Tomsk, Ryazan, Yaroslavl, Blagoveshchensk, and others.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: Journalists from Russian regions visited China's largest cities as part of a press tour in November 2023. The media representatives visited Beijing, Xi'an, and Chengdu, where they familiarized themselves with the history and development of these major cities, as well as cultural attractions of global significance.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Academia.note: Agree, as far as we can see, Russian journalists from state-owned media mostly participate in bilateral media forums or dialogues (https://rg.ru/2023/09/22/26-sentiabria-kitajsko-rossijskij-dialog-molodyh-zhurnalistov.html) and new media forums (https://tass.ru/press-relizy/13076523), which usually means new ways of spreading the information of traditional media via the internet.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There are several instances where universities cooperate with each other to create joint educational programs. There are at least five such programs. However, their footprint is relatively insignificant because they enroll a limited number of students.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: Such articles are extremely scarce. There is only one article that whitewashes human rights abuses.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Russia and China signed a cooperation agreement on the Far East route. Another instance is the international cooperation between the border regions of the Russian Federation, the PRC, Mongolia, and Kazakhstan within the framework of the International Coordination Council "Our Common Home - Altai." Additionally, there is a Memorandum of Understanding between the Ministry for the Development of the Far East and the Arctic of the Russian Federation and the Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China on industrial and infrastructure cooperation in the preferential regimes of the Russian Far East.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: There are 366 partnerships between the regions of the two countries, including 135 at the regional level and 231 at the municipal level. To date, 59 constituent entities of the Russian Federation have agreements with PRC regions, and about 100 municipalities have sister cities or partners in China.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: All levels of government make regular trips to China, but it is not disclosed who pays for these trips. Therefore, it is not possible to give an estimate.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence:
A Russian parliamentary delegation has completed a visit to China—an example of a trip by members of the State Duma.

Head of the Russian Government, Mikhail Mishustin, together with a delegation of heads of agencies and state corporations, completed their two-day visit to China—an example of a trip by members of the Russian Government.

A delegation from the Ulyanovsk region went to China—an example of a trip by regional authorities.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: As the ruling party, the CCP maintains strong ties with the United Russia party, whose representatives have been participating in World Political Parties Summits and Dialogues with World Political Parties High-Level Meetings since the mid-2010s. Moreover, on an ideological basis, the CCP invites the Russian Communist Party to participate in the annual World Socialism Forum, organized by the China Academy of Social Sciences. Furthermore, United Russia has been holding a Dialogue with the CCP annually; on November 23, 2023, the two parties organized the 10th Dialogue within the cross-ruling parties cooperation framework.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.note: Even during the initial stage of the COVID-19 pandemic outbreak, China did not criticize Russian officials for banning its citizens from entering Russia. Russia was one of the first countries to close its border with China in February 2020 (https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/4260060).
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Approval of China's policies has been voiced at various levels of government, mostly in positive terms.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.note: There is no coordinated criticism of Chinese policies (even on issues like Xinjiang and Hong Kong), and most Russians, according to sociological surveys, look favorably on the PRC (https://www.levada.ru/2023/09/12/velikie-strany-otnoshenie-k-ssha-es-kitayu-i-ukraine-grazhdanam-etih-stran/). As a result, there is no need for the Russian government to suppress critics of the PRC, even when they articulate some criticism on the internet.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: China has become Russia's main trade partner after a sharp decline in imports from the EU, Kiel analysts reported. According to their calculations, Russia's trade with European countries decreased by 43%, while trade with China increased by 23%.
Economy.note: In 2023, after the introduction of several sanctions from the West, including a ban on exporting devices over $200 to Russia, China significantly increased imports of Chinese mobile phones into Russia. These phones are now distributed with pre-installed Russian application stores (RuStore). Chinese manufacturers now occupy 75% of the mobile device market, which is 25% more than a year earlier. It is evident that control over devices imported into the country with pre-installed and government-approved applications allows for increased control and censorship in the Russian online space.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: China is one of Russia's largest partners. For example, China has been the largest buyer of Russian oil since 2017. In 2021, China purchased 70.1 million tons of oil from Russia (30.6% of Russia's total oil exports) for $34.9 billion. When it comes to specific countries buying Russian non-resource products, the UK ($20.2 billion) and China ($16.3 billion) are the leaders.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: China is a major investor in Russia, with Chinese entities holding stakes in sensitive sectors ranging from 25% to 50%. Back in 2006, a Russian oil company was fully owned by Sinopec before 51% of its shares were sold to Rosneft. In October 2023, a mutual fund was established for investing in aviation, big data, energy-efficient technologies, and the space industry.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: On March 28, 2015, Russia decided to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), established at the initiative of China. This was announced by Igor Shuvalov, First Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Federation. Chinese President Xi Jinping welcomed Russia's decision to join the AIIB, as stated by Chinese Finance Minister Luo Jiwei. On April 14, 2015, Russia became a potential founding member of the AIIB.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Economy.note: By mid-2023, around 30 Russian banks had joined the CIPS system (and as local newspapers highlight, banks use it indirectly) (https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/6002383). The reason for Russia using this system is a lack of alternatives: after the war in Ukraine started, several major Russian banks were sanctioned and restricted from using the SWIFT system (https://www.forbes.ru/finansy/457717-es-otklucil-ot-swift-sem-rossijskih-bankov).
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: According to the link provided by an expert, Russia and China have agreed to create "an era of free trade" but not a free trade zone. Another link emphasizes that the Sino-Russia Agreement on Trade and Economic Relations (2010) and its conditions do not apply to preferences provided by Russia to free-trade zone and Customs Union members. The reason why Russia has not signed a free-trade agreement with China is obvious: the flow of cheap Chinese goods would flood the market if it happens (https://www.rbc.ru/newspaper/2016/06/30/577384109a7947b2789bb872). Even the current Russian ambassador to China, Igor Morgulov, mentioned in an interview that the two sides are discussing the possibility of signing such an agreement in the future (https://russiancouncil.ru/analytics-and-comments/comments/v-sotrudnichestve-rossii-i-knr-net-predelov-i-zapretnykh-zon/), but this story is long-lasting and may not come to a conclusion soon.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: China is investing in Special Economic Zones in the Russian Federation. Currently, tax relief is at the stage of discussions and proposals.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Technology.evidence: China Telecom, one of the largest Chinese operators providing traffic transmission services in the Russian Federation, plans to expand its presence in the country, including increasing brand recognition. China Unicom (277 million subscribers in China, with a representative office in Russia since June 2017) and China Mobile (867 million subscribers, operating in Russia since 2018) also operate in the field of cross-border traffic transmission in Russia.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Technology.evidence: Large telecommunications companies signed multimillion-dollar contracts with Huawei. MTS spent 7.5 billion rubles to modernize its 5G network in Moscow using equipment from China's Huawei. "VimpelCom" (brand "Beeline") received a large batch of equipment from Chinese Huawei. After the start of the special military operation, Huawei stopped concluding new contracts for the supply of equipment to Russia but continued to fulfill its obligations under the existing contracts.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Technology.evidence: In our expert's opinion, all Russian equipment for SORM and TSPU is reworked Chinese equipment. It is not officially authorized, but all Russian equipment is converted from Chinese sources.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Technology.evidence: Yes, for example, there are a couple of them.

Technology.evidence: Russia and China signed a program of cooperation in space activities until 2027. They also signed an agreement on cooperation to ensure the complementarity of the GLONASS and Beidou global navigation satellite systems.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Society.evidence: No groups with this name could be found, but there are internet publishers that publish information on this topic in a positive way.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Society.evidence: Such activities exist, but there is no disclosure of their funding.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Society.evidence: In our expert's opinion, yes, but proof is hard to find; only high-profile cases are known.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Society.evidence: Please refer to the supporting evidence.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Society.evidence: TikTok is among the top 5 social networks/messaging apps in Russia according to Mediascope. In 2023, it ranked 2nd, 3rd, or 4th, depending on the criteria or the entity preparing the statistics. Mediascope states that TikTok has the highest average time spent in the app among its competitors. The Association of Communication Agencies of Russia (in Russian: АКАР) places TikTok in 5th place, noting that the overall top 5 list is undergoing changes due to sanctions.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Society.evidence:
There is a Chinese Cultural Center in Moscow. Also, at the beginning of 2024, Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered the implementation of the Years of Chinese and Russian Cultures in both countries. Bilateral cultural events are numerous, and those organized in Russia are usually funded or sponsored by the Chinese government or other entities.

Examples include:
- Chinese Bridge competition (Confucius Institute, Huawei, Embassy)
- Inter-University Chinese Poetry Competition (IBS, Moscow; funded by Bank of China (Russia) and CRCC)
- Days of Chinese Movies in Moscow (annual, organized/sponsored by China's State Administration on Films and China Cinema Archive)
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Society.evidence: To China, yes, specifically to the government—this is unclear. However, according to a March poll by VTsIOM, "a third of Russians believe that our country should perceive China as a friendly state." The FOM survey provides more details, referring to China as Russia's number one economic partner and explaining the reasons. Nevertheless, China occupies only the second place, after Belarus, as the country with the most mutual understanding.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Military.evidence: In the past, there have been instances of individual purchases of communications equipment and helmets from the PRC, but these were not part of government policy.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Military.evidence:
1. Beijing Xiangshan Forum 2021, Minister of Defense Sergey Shoigu
2. World Peace Forum 2022, Igor Ivanov, President of the Russian International Affairs Council
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Military.evidence: In terms of Russian aircraft engine supplies to China, cooperation is being seriously curtailed, if not phased out, as China develops its own aircraft engine production. On its part, Russia is trying to extend these supplies as long as possible.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Military.evidence: In June 2023, Russian Chief of General Staff Valery Gerasimov held talks with Liu Zhengli, head of the Joint Staff of China's Central Military Council. In April 2023, a Chinese delegation visited the Military Academy of the General Staff, and more than 20 Chinese servicemen are set to start their education there in the autumn. In August 2023, there was a bilateral meeting between the Ministries of Defense of the two countries.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Military.evidence: Two former colonels, who are regularly hosted on federal mainstream talk shows, hold a rather reserved stance. They either state that China is taking a position of "neutral or cautious support towards Russia," or they suggest that Russia should follow the logic of political realism, keeping in mind that "the only Chinese ally is China itself."
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Military.evidence: In our expert's opinion, the joint exercises with China play a largely demonstrative and political role for Moscow. These exercises are aimed at a global audience and, first and foremost, at the West, rather than practically practicing coalition actions.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Russia and China have a treaty on mutual legal assistance in civil and criminal matters. This treaty provides a framework for cooperation between the two countries in the prosecution of criminal offenses, exchange of information, assistance in legal proceedings, extradition, and other legal procedures. However, Russia and China do not have a common extradition treaty.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Cooperation between Russia and China in the field of counterterrorism does exist, where law enforcement agencies of the two countries work together to exchange information, develop joint operations, and coordinate efforts to counter the terrorist threat.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

Law Enforcement.evidence: There is information about the presence of some criminal groups associated with the Chinese Triad in Russia. According to U.S. researchers, branches of well-known Chinese triads such as Big Circle, 14K, Red Sun, and Sun Yee On are currently active in Russia.

Law Enforcement.evidence: The training of fifteen employees of the prosecutor's office of the People's Republic of China has been completed. For the first time in the history of the University, Chinese prosecutors received advanced training under the Agreement between the Prosecutor General's Office of the Russian Federation and the Supreme People's Procuratorate of the People's Republic of China. Additionally, fifteen employees of the Russian prosecutor's office also received training in Beijing.

Law Enforcement.evidence:
In 2015, Russia and China signed an agreement of mutual non-aggression in cyberspace. However, Chinese hackers, backed by the government or acting independently, have been attacking Russian critical infrastructure and companies for years.
In 2023, attacks targeted several Russian companies, including telecom operators, software designers, and vendors.
According to Kaspersky (an antivirus software development company), in the first seven months of 2016, Chinese hackers attacked Russian defense, nuclear, and other critical infrastructure 194 times.
